G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: This action arises from a residential tenancy in Springfield, Massachusetts and from Defendant’s breach of the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14.

G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19 and related statutes because the amount in controversy is within the jurisdictional limits of the District Court and the claims arise under Massachusetts law.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 8.proposition: Venue is proper in the Springfield District Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, § 8 because the Premises are located in Springfield, Massachusetts, and the events giving rise to this action occurred in this venue.

Mass. Gen. Laws c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Mass. Gen. Laws c. 186, § 14 provides, in relevant part, that a landlord shall not “directly or indirectly interfere with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant.”

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 716\.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, the covenant of quiet enjoyment is implied in every residential lease and tenancy, whether oral or written.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 716\.support_reasoning: The opinion repeatedly refers to an "implied covenant" or "implied warranty" of quiet enjoyment and applies it to these tenants, but it does not expressly state that such a covenant is implied in every Massachusetts residential lease or tenancy, oral or written. The case assumes the existence of an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment and focuses on when a landlord's conduct breaches it, not on the universal scope of its implication across all residential arrangements. Thus it is consistent with, but does not clearly establish, the broad proposition claimed.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 716\.relevant_excerpt: The judge found that the tenants were “very substantially deprived” of quiet enjoyment of their leased premises “for a substantial time” (emphasis original). He ruled that the tenants’ implied warranty of quiet enjoyment was violated by late evening and early morning music and disturbances coming from nearby premises which the landlords leased to others for use as a bar or cocktail lounge (lounge). The landlords argue that they did not violate the tenants’ implied covenant of quiet enjoyment because they are not chargeable with the noise from the lounge.

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, the covenant of quiet enjoyment is implied in every residential lease and tenancy, whether oral or written.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely states, in its discussion of G.L. c. 186, § 14 and the common-law background, that every tenancy carries an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb the tenant’s quiet enjoyment. It does not limit this to written leases or to any particular formality, instead using the broad term “every tenancy,” which in Massachusetts encompasses residential tenancies whether oral or written. Thus, the case affirmatively supports the proposition that the covenant of quiet enjoyment is implied in every residential lease or tenancy.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy…. Every tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right during the tenancy. Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977).” (Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102 (1982).)

Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.raw_text: Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761–62 (1979)
Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.proposition: A landlord’s failure to correct conditions that materially impair the character and value of the leased premises, when the landlord has notice and a reasonable opportunity to repair, can constitute an unlawful interference with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment.
Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.support_reasoning: The court expressly accepts the Housing Court judge’s conclusion that the unrepaired, leaking roof both breached the implied warranty of habitability and interfered with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14. The opinion treats the landlord’s failure to repair serious defects (after notice and opportunity) as actionable interference with quiet enjoyment, and then discusses the proper measure of damages under § 14, thereby supporting the stated proposition that such failures can constitute unlawful interference with quiet enjoyment.
Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “The BHA does not challenge the judge’s conclusion that its failures to repair the leaky roof and the defective floors were breaches of its implied warranty of habitability or his determination that the leaky roof interfered with the plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment of the leased premises.… Section 14 of G. L. c. 186 expands the measure of damages to include all ‘actual and consequential damages’ where, as here, there has been a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 283–84 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: A landlord’s failure to correct conditions that materially impair the character and value of the leased premises, when the landlord has notice and a reasonable opportunity to repair, can constitute an unlawful interference with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The court explicitly interprets the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment to cover serious interferences with tenancy arising from a landlord’s omissions, including failing to take available measures to address conditions that substantially impair the tenant’s use of the premises. It holds that if the landlord, with notice, “failed to take any action” to remove persons engaged in unlawful activity, thereby allowing a condition that seriously interferes with the tenancy to persist, this may constitute a breach of quiet enjoyment. That aligns with the proposition that a landlord’s failure to correct materially impairing conditions after notice and opportunity can be an unlawful interference with quiet enjoyment.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy — acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leasehold… a landlord may not intend to violate a tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment, but may do so nevertheless when the breach is a ‘natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done.’ … If the defendant failed to take any action to remove from the area of its control persons engaged in unlawful activity, then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies of the plaintiffs and thus breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.raw_text: Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771, 774–76 (1994)
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, § 14, an “act or omission” by the landlord that results in an interruption of “services” to which the tenant is entitled can be a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment and may entitle the tenant to recover actual or statutory damages.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.support_reasoning: The opinion mentions G.L. c. 186, § 14 only in passing and explicitly notes that although the judge found a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, no damages were awarded on that claim because they would have been duplicative. The case is focused on measuring damages for breach of the implied warranty of habitability in a subsidized tenancy, not on interpreting § 14’s “act or omission” or “services” language, nor on when such an interruption constitutes a breach of quiet enjoyment or gives rise to actual or statutory damages. It therefore does not establish or analyze the legal principle stated in the proposition.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.relevant_excerpt: “The judge also awarded Wideman the equivalent of two months’ rent on her retaliation claim under G. L. c. 186, § 18. No issue is raised as to these damages on appeal. Although the judge found a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, he awarded no damages on this claim to avoid what would have been a duplicative award. See Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 107-111 (1982).”

Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.raw_text: Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982, 983 (1982)
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, § 14, an “act or omission” by the landlord that results in an interruption of “services” to which the tenant is entitled can be a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment and may entitle the tenant to recover actual or statutory damages.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.support_reasoning: The opinion holds that the landlords’ failure to furnish heat—an essential service—to which the tenant was entitled constituted a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, and that the tenant was entitled to damages and fees. The court emphasizes that liability arises based on the landlord’s conduct (the act or omission causing interruption of services), not intent, and remands for assessment of damages under § 14. This directly supports the proposition that an act or omission resulting in interruption of services can breach quiet enjoyment and lead to actual or statutory damages.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.relevant_excerpt: “A landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season…constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment… It is not necessary to recovery that the landlord intended to violate the covenant. Rather ‘the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling.’… liability will be imposed ‘whenever the “natural and probable consequence” of [the] landlord’s action [is] interruption of the tenant’s rights.’… [T]he tenant was entitled… [to] an assessment of damages and counsel fees under § 14.”

Hemingway v. O\u2019Brien, 363 Mass. 359.proposition: The provision of safe, functional electrical service to a bedroom in a residential apartment is a basic service essential to the normal, safe, and reasonable use of the premises, and its prolonged interruption constitutes a substantial interference with quiet enjoyment.
Hemingway v. O\u2019Brien, 363 Mass. 359.case_name: Board of Appeals of Hanover v. Housing Appeals Comm.
Hemingway v. O\u2019Brien, 363 Mass. 359.support_reasoning: The opinion is a zoning and land-use decision about Massachusetts General Laws c. 40B and the power to override exclusionary zoning for low- and moderate‑income housing. It does not discuss landlord‑tenant law, quiet enjoyment, or the nature of basic services in a residential apartment, nor does it address electrical service or interference with a tenant’s use of premises. Accordingly, it provides no authority for the proposition that loss of safe, functional electrical service to a bedroom constitutes a substantial interference with quiet enjoyment.
Hemingway v. O\u2019Brien, 363 Mass. 359.relevant_excerpt: The case concerns whether c. 774 (G. L. c. 40B, §§ 20–23) confers power on local boards and the Housing Appeals Committee to override zoning regulations that hamper the construction of low and moderate income housing, and whether that power is constitutional. It contains no discussion of residential services, utilities, or quiet enjoyment in a landlord‑tenant context.

G.L. c. 111, \u00a7\u00a7 127A, 127L.proposition: The provision of safe, functional electrical service to a bedroom in a residential apartment is a basic service essential to the normal, safe, and reasonable use of the premises, and its prolonged interruption constitutes a substantial interference with quiet enjoyment.

105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq..proposition: The Massachusetts State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq., requires that a dwelling unit be provided with adequate and safe electricity and lighting, including outlets and fixtures, in every habitable room.

105 C.M.R. 410.250\u2013410.260.proposition: The Massachusetts State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq., requires that a dwelling unit be provided with adequate and safe electricity and lighting, including outlets and fixtures, in every habitable room.

Blackett, 371 Mass. at 718\u201319.proposition: The lack of electricity in the Office Bedroom has rendered that room effectively unusable and has materially impaired the value, safety, and habitability of the Apartment, thereby substantially interfering with Plaintiff’s use and enjoyment of the Premises.

Darmetko, 378 Mass. at 761\u201362.proposition: The lack of electricity in the Office Bedroom has rendered that room effectively unusable and has materially impaired the value, safety, and habitability of the Apartment, thereby substantially interfering with Plaintiff’s use and enjoyment of the Premises.

Al Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.proposition: The interference with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment has been continuous and substantial, as Plaintiff has lost the use of one of her two bedrooms and has been compelled to incur extra expenses and to rearrange her living space in ways that significantly detract from the normal enjoyment of her home.
Al Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.support_reasoning: This opinion concerns whether a statutory lead-paint violation, without proof of landlord fault, constitutes a violation of the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment. It discusses the fault standard (at least negligence) required under G.L. c. 186, § 14, but does not address what constitutes ‘continuous and substantial’ interference, loss of use of rooms, extra expenses, or rearrangement of living space. Therefore it does not support the specific proposition about the nature and extent of interference with quiet enjoyment described in the claimed proposition.
Al Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.relevant_excerpt: “We noted that a landlord’s failure ‘to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.’ See Cruz, supra at 789, citing Simon v. Solomon, supra at 103 (failure to control floods in tenant’s apartment); Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761 (1979) (failure to repair leaky roof); Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959, 960 (1985) (failure to bring apartment into habitable condition and keep it so).”

Wolfberg v. Hunter, 385 Mass. 390, 402\u.proposition: The interference with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment has been continuous and substantial, as Plaintiff has lost the use of one of her two bedrooms and has been compelled to incur extra expenses and to rearrange her living space in ways that significantly detract from the normal enjoyment of her home.
Wolfberg v. Hunter, 385 Mass. 390, 402\u.support_reasoning: The opinion does recognize "substantial interference with the use and enjoyment of the apartment" sufficient to constitute a loss of property for damages purposes, but it does not discuss or find facts about loss of use of a particular bedroom, rearranging living space, or incurring extra expenses in the way described in the proposition. The cited pages focus on the legal characterization and calculation of damages under G.L. c. 93A and c. 239, § 8A, not on a detailed description of continuous and substantial interference with quiet enjoyment of specific rooms. Thus the proposition overstates and mischaracterizes what this case actually says.
Wolfberg v. Hunter, 385 Mass. 390, 402\u.relevant_excerpt: “We believe that the judge erred in thus resolving the issues raised by the plaintiff’s claim for damages. There has been a substantial interference with the use and enjoyment of the apartment to which the tenants were entitled under their lease. This interference with a right guaranteed to them under their lease constitutes a loss of property to the tenants. They had a contractual right to enjoy the use of the apartment free of rodents. The judge found that the tenants withheld rent justifiably.”

Doe, 417 Mass. at 283\u201384.proposition: Defendant had both the right and the practical ability to undertake and complete the repairs necessary to restore electricity to the Office Bedroom, and his failure to do so within a reasonable time was unreasonable and without legal justification.

Cruz Mgmt. Co., 417 Mass. at 774\u201376.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, § 14, a landlord who violates the tenant’s quiet enjoyment is liable for “actual and consequential damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater, and the costs of the action, including a reasonable attorney’s fee,” even if the tenant is self‑represented.

Wolfberg, 385 Mass. at 402\u201304.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, § 14, a landlord who violates the tenant’s quiet enjoyment is liable for “actual and consequential damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater, and the costs of the action, including a reasonable attorney’s fee,” even if the tenant is self‑represented.

Simon, 385 Mass. at 110\u201311.proposition: Plaintiff is therefore entitled to recover her actual and consequential damages resulting from Defendant’s breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, or three months’ rent, whichever is greater, together with costs and such further relief as this Court deems just and proper.
